question.title: Class jakarta.persistence.GenerationType does not have member field 'jakarta.persistence.GenerationType UUID'
question.body:
I want to save objects of my java application in a sqlite database. I decided to use hibernate because it seemed very easy to model the relational database as java classes. When I want to use the jakarta persistence library I get the following error

2025-04-07T14:54:09.825+02:00 ERROR 31103 --- [modellbahn] [           main] o.s.boot.SpringApplication               : Application run failed

 org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'entityManagerFactory' defined in class path resource [org/springframework/boot/autoconfigure/orm/jpa/HibernateJpaConfiguration.class]: Class jakarta.persistence.GenerationType does not have member field 'jakarta.persistence.GenerationType UUID'
    at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.initializeBean(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:1806) ~[spring-beans-6.1.13.jar:6.1.13]
    at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.doCreateBean(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:600) ~[spring-beans-6.1.13.jar:6.1.13]
    at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.createBean(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:522) ~[spring-beans-6.1.13.jar:6.1.13]

Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: Class jakarta.persistence.GenerationType does not have member field 'jakarta.persistence.GenerationType UUID'

Process finished with exit code 1

This is one of my java classes :

package de.dhbwkarlsruhe.modellbahn.database.entities;

import de.dhbwkarlsruhe.modellbahn.Models.SimpleLocValue;
import lombok.Getter;
import lombok.Setter;


import jakarta.persistence.Entity;
import jakarta.persistence.Id;
import jakarta.persistence.Table;
import java.time.Instant;

@Entity
@Table
@Getter
@Setter
public class Value
{
    @Id
    private int ValueID;

    private int TypeID;
    private String TimeStamp;
    private int Value;
    private int Loc;

    public static Value createValue(SimpleLocValue model)
    {
        Value value = new Value();
        value.setValue(model.getValue());
        value.setLoc(model.getLoc());
        value.setTypeID(0);

        value.setTimeStamp(Instant.now().toString());
        return value;
    }
}

And this is the relevant part of my build.gradle.kts

    implementation("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-websocket")
    implementation("commons-codec:commons-codec:1.18.0")
    // database driver
    implementation("org.xerial:sqlite-jdbc:3.41.2.2")
    //dialect for hibernate
    implementation("com.github.gwenn:sqlite-dialect:0.1.0")
    implementation("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-data-jpa")
    implementation("jakarta.persistence:jakarta.persistence-api:3.0.0")
    implementation("org.hibernate:hibernate-core:6.2.0.Final")
    compileOnly("org.projectlombok:lombok")

answers.body:
Wrong version

GenerationType.UUID was added in Jakarta EE 10. Jakarta Persistence (JPA) 3.0 (then one you're using) is part of Jakarta EE 9. You'll need at least version 3.1 of Jakarta Persistence to be able to use GenerationType.UUID.

M. Deinum's comment is the correct answer. The latest spring-boot-starter-data-jpa version (3.4.4) gives you Hibernate 6.6.11.Final and JPA 3.1. I've checked older versions as well, and everything from Spring Boot 3.1.0 onwards gives you JPA 3.1. Spring Boot 3.0.x still gives you JPA 3.0 so that's out of the question.

If you are using an old Hibernate and JPA(before 3.1), try to use Hiberante specific UUID geneator.


@Entity
class SampleEntity{

    @Id
    @GeneratedValue(generator = "uuid-hibernate-generator")
    @GenericGenerator(name = "uuid-hibernate-generator", strategy = "org.hibernate.id.UUIDGenerator")
    private UUID id;

    // other fields

    //getters and setters
}

question_comments.body: YOu can mark the question from Rob Spoor as the right one, that already contains the information and proper answer (and a reference to my comment).
Could you please post your first comment as an answer so I can mark this question as solved

Don't override hibernate in that way. If you want to use another version just specify hibernate.version as a property. But spring-boot-starter-data-jpa already includes a certain compatible version, managing it yourself might (and eventually will) lead incompatible versions in use.

Thank you. Removing the persistence-api helped I still ended up using the hibernate-core library but with version 6.6 and I added hibernate-community-dialects because hibernate doesn't need the sqlite-dialect explicitly.

Remove the persistence-api and hibernate-core dependency (spring-boot-starter-data-jpa already pulls in the right versions). Also please properly format your stacktrace using code tags and not using quote tags, currently it is totally unreadable.
